d:entry.p: verb, 3rd conjugation (perfect infinitive: cecinisse; supine: cantum)

ol.li: to sing, sing of : "Arma virumque cano" – Arms and a man I sing
(in war) to sound (the signal) : signum (receptui) canere – to sound the signal (for retreat)
(with abl.) to play (an instrument) : tibia canere – to play the flute.

d:entry.d:title: homō
d:entry.p: noun, masculine or feminine, 3rd declension (genitive: hominis)

d:entry.d:title: hominī
d:entry.p: noun, masculine or feminine, 3rd declension (genitive: hominis)
noun, masculine or feminine, 3rd declension (genitive: hominis)
noun, masculine or feminine, 3rd declension (genitive: hominis)

d:entry.d:title: hominēs
d:entry.p: noun, masculine or feminine, 3rd declension (genitive: hominis)
noun, masculine or feminine, 3rd declension (genitive: hominis)
noun, masculine or feminine, 3rd declension (genitive: hominis)
ORIGIN French, from thè 'tea', based on Chinese 茶 (chá) 'tea'

d:entry.d:title: uocāre
d:entry.p: verb, 1st conjugation (perfect infinitive: uocāvisse; supine: uocātum)

ol.li: to call, summon, invoke (someone or something)
(with doub. acc.) to name, designate : eum amicum uoco – I call him a friend
to bring or put into a state or condition : uocare in dubium – to call into question
